artist: Designer: Jean Otis Reinecke; Manufacturer: Chicago Electrical Manufacturing
creditline: The Modernism Collection, gift of Norwest Bank Minnesota
medium: Chromium-plated metal, painted metal, Bakelite, electrical components
text: Initially a British invention of the early 1890s, the toaster was the first domestic appliance to make use of the new power source -- electricity. A Stillwater designer, Charles Strite, patented the first pop-up toaster in 1919. Named the Toastmaster, it was put into production for restaurant use by the Waters-Genter Company of Minneapolis in 1921. Though the form remained essentially the same, the "HandyHot" toaster was produced in several variations, the emphasis continually on compact geometry.
title: "Handy Hot" toaster, model AEUB
